Why in the comment section of a man's obituary do you all engage in a sophomoric dialogue on who was superior - Buckley or Vidal?

They were both witty, intelligent -- and, sometimes mean-spirited -- fellows; and the world is less interesting without both them.

Gore Vidal never wrote a clumsy or dull sentence. Yes. his body of work was, I think, unmatched by any writer in the last century (including Mailer and that soi-disant novelist William F. Buckley.) But the crown of his achievement was in the essay. Many of the obits have compared him to Montaigne. a comparison that Vidal would have found ridiculous. While he honored and learned from Montaigne. Gore Vidal was comparable only to...Gore Vidal. He brought to the essay form not only the economy that comes with elegance and precision but also an almost terrifying, autodidact erudition. I often imagined meeting him--and being tongue-tied. What could one say to a man who said so much, and said it so well?

A great deal of his work will be read over many years to come--and that will not be true of the "professoriate" that disdained him for his lack of academic credentials.

Vidal fought against what (Catholic) theology calls "invincible ignorance" (a species of blindness that the church and the American electorate has brought to a standard not matched since the 14th century).

We did not deserve him and the gifts he gave to us. I once thought his contrarian view of American history was a bit skewed, to put it mildly. After living for over 70 years, I find his views distressingly on target.
Well then save voicing your opinion until you have read them.  They are not to be missed.

He will be remembered as an essayist. although I have enjoyed several of his novels. I really admired his skills as a partisan essayist even when I disagreed sometimes with his point of view.  And his essays are so humorous. He was a great wit,.
Several of Vidal's novels are entertaining, but not great art. Perhaps his essays are better - haven't gotten around to sampling them yet.

Gore Vidal left a treasured legacy of literature to not only America but to the world. His historic novels should be required reading for all history majors. His essays should be assigned to members of debating teams for the interesting topics they represent. His interviews on TV on the Dick Cavet, Johnny Carson, Charlie Rose Shows and on NPR-Radio live on thanks to the Internet.

I believe he was related to Lady Gregory, a co-founder of the famed Abbey Theatre in Dublin, Ireland along with George Bernard Shaw, William Butler Yeats and Edward Martyn to mention a few of Ireland's literary greats. Lady Gregory was a member of the Gore Family in Ireland.

Some might say Gore Vidal was to our era what Oscar Wilde's writing was to his era. Gore is, was and will always be more to many of us.

Jacqueline A. Beusse

Arizona is on the front line of two decades of failure of the Federal Adminstration to do its job and enforce the US immigration laws.

If it was not for Sheriff Joe the Maricopa County and indeed the state of Arizona would now have a much bigger problem with illegal immigration. A very expensive budget busting problem as other states are finding. Sheriff Joe helped share the problem around, he helped push the problem Northward so the entire US could share the pain of the Federal Adminstations failures.

I'm sure many adminstrators, whether they are Hispanic in origin or not, in the states of California, New Mexico and Texas are quietly now wishing that they had a Sheriff Joe enforcing the laws in more of their counties over the last two decades.

I am all for our law enforcement officers being brought to account where they have broken the law but I am totally against a law enforcement officier being singled out for treatment because they have been enforcing important laws that the federal government has chosen not to enforce. And I get particular angry when those law enforcement officiers being singled out are in the states and counties most affected by the Federal Governments failures.

801avd: "I don't think you have to worry too much about seeing physical fights break out in Congress ..."

In the 19th C. there were fistfights and even weapons drawn. If the Tea Party wants to return to first principles, I wouldn't count it out.

In 1798, Connectict Congressman Roger Griswald attacked Vermont Congressman Matthew Lyon on the House of Representatives floor with a hickory walking stick. Lyon counter attacked with at-hand fire tongs, while the Speaker and others looked on with delight.

As we all know, Hamilton's verbal attacks on Burr cost Hamilton his life.

A wonderful account of those early years of vicious quarrels, slander, duel challenges is Joanne B. Freeman's "Affiars of Honor: National Politics in the New Republic..

I agree with you about the fights that can soon take place. And, don't be surprised if you see a white male Republican hit a woman Congressperson or Senator. Their frustration and inability to articulate a vision will lead to non-verbal aggression.

Ever see those video clips of fist fights in various Parliaments around the world? When I watched these clips, I can remember thinking to myself, no matter how partisan our Congress becomes you'd never see that here. Well, sadly, I just wouldn't say that anymore. Considering the type of politicians running on the GOP ticket, and the disturbing things they often say, I wouldn't be surprised as I once would've if I saw a fight break out during a roll call vote.

The fact that I wouldn't be surprised to see a melee in the halls of the US congress, speaks volumes about how low we've sunk in the last decade when it comes to who we're electing to high office.

Aside from the fact that the Tea Party has actually managed to make their movement synonymous with the word 'Constitution' -- a living document that if it could talk would no doubt express outrage over the fact that it's become a weapon in the hands of those who do everything to distort what it actually stands for --America's "third party" is capitalizing at the polls on an electorate that apparently can no longer separate fact from fiction. Everyday we seem to hear something nutty from one of these Tea Party zealots that would make you think they have finally gone too far. But, they still win; they still find supporters who embrace their cause.

It was John Dean who once said there was a cancer growing on the Presidency. I suppose it's our turn to say there's a cancer growing on the GOP, and we better do something about it.

If, as in the past, a majority of registered voters do not exercise their rights, the Sheriff will continue his platform. And, only Arizonans can be responsible for that!

Correction.  "The people of Arizona" have not made him widely popular - voters in Maricopa County who continue to vote for him have that dubious honor. Leave Pima County and the rest of reasonable Arizonans out of this!

This Sheriff's actions tell us not so much about himself but about the nature of his support.  While not every action taken will be admired without some hesitation,  it is important that a basic centrist like  Mitt Romney sought and enjoys his endorsement.  The people of Arizona have made him widely popular and famous world wide.   He clearly articulates one aspect of  the war that is at work in our civic, cultural, and economic life.   It's the war that ultimately matters the most since it will decide our fate and that of our role in the world.  To the victor will go the spoils.
I see the craziness in my state. We are in the 21st century. We don't need to elect sheriffs or prosecutors. They should be professionals hired by a professional county administrator.

Arpaio? He's the cultural progeny of Bull Connor - utterly anachronistic yet wholly indicative of the social pessimism, misanthropy and ruthless meanness of present day tea party conservatism. Arpaio is ossified by-product,  a bit of fascist social detritus,  that crawled out of the cultural and social time warp  that has overtaken the US.

Sheriff Joe is not my hero.

But I think he has done a very important job for Maricopa County and the Arizona state also.

A JOB where he had to make himself unpopular to make it clear that his county was going to enforce US Federal immigration laws even if the US Federal Government wasn't.

People in the US are going to find that if they want to successfully enforce US immigration laws in the face of the billions of people around the world who would love to come to the US, then the immigration laws will not only need to be enforced in a tough and uncompromising way, they will need to be SEEN to be enforced in a tough and uncompromising way.

A half hearted approach, which is all that can ever be offered by Obama and the Democrats will not work, not in the long run. To see this you only need to see that illegal immigrant numbers have stabalised or gone down slightly at best and this is in spite of the toughest immigration enforcement in decades and the worst recession in the US in 70 years. If the US doesn't get tough about enforcement numbers will soon rise again.

Thanks, Martin. There've been many queries about "rebus" applied to crossword puzzles, but none of the answers have ever explained the subject so thoroughly and succinctly before.

Thanks Martin, but my point was that the in the traditional rebus the picture is in the clues, not the answers. Hieroglyphs are a form of rebus. These puzzles are not. But I guess there's no use fighting the tide, and the usage seems to have changed.

princeton08540,

May I just call you 08540? I get the point you're making, but you're correct -- right or wrong, the name is pretty well established.

I point out that many early rebuses were heraldic, and it's hard to say whether the rebus element is "clue" or "answer." For instance, the coat of arms of Ignatius Loyola contains a wolf and a pot ("lobo" and "olla"):
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Familie_wapen_Loyola.JPG

It's more likely that one would learn to remember the "lo-olla" rebus as Loyola rather than translate the coat of arms in a vacuum.

In other words, there have always been verbis-rebus as well as rebus-verbis uses. And the crossword use certainly fits the dictum 'not with words, but with pictures."

Good point. With Republican states laying off government workers it may be long lines at the DMV. And you have to wonder if many of them will be able to accurately recognize other states' birth certificates. It says it all when NRA ID cards are valid but not university ones.

James, you DO realize that not everyone reads newspapers? I mean really, that is part of the problem here in the US with the woefully under-educated electorate we seem to have.

Too bad the people who "should" be excluded - you know, the really dumb followers who parrot the latest from Faux and Rush everyday, but those people get rallied up by their hysterical masters, and they'll be sure to vote to keep those masters in control.

It's the people who are out there busy surviving who may not have time to read or get that ID. You know, those POOR people who work just to eat, should they really be mandated to jump through even more hoops to cast their vote? Of course they should, if they want to vote Democratic that is.
And again, the fact that an ID is most likely NOT issued free of charge just makes this a form of poll tax.  I thought we'd outlawed that?

Have people started trying to obtain the photo IDs and discovered whether the system works as purported?  If the offices involved are flooded with requests and questions, are they able to handle them?  If the system is too difficult for people to navigate successfully in practice, for whatever reason, maybe that would also help make the case that the requirements operate as an unreasonable restraint on a person's right to vote, regardless of whatever imagined ill the requirements are supposedly redressing.

Instead of combating voter "suppression" I would put this time in effort into getting these people IDs.  Everyone would be happy then.  They would be better off and  we would reduce the possibility of voting fraud.  If an illegal vote is cast, a legal voter has been disenfranchised.  People have died for their rights to vote and people will fight to keep it.  Why fight these people when there is a obvious solution that is best for all involved?  Unless of course, the people fighting the voter ID laws are actually fighting because they want there to be illegal votes cast.  I like to think that's not true.  People who are knowingly trying to get votes counted from ineligible voters should be sent away for a long time.  The integrity of our elections is important.
Bill,  What about ensuring the integrity of the voting machines and the vote counters?  Remember Florida 2000?
Agreed. I wonder if the most effective response to these efforts to disenfranchise poor and minority voters wouldn't be to make sure that those same voters have, and use, absentee ballots.

Thank you for concentrating on this subject, Charles, and please keep at it.  Voter suppression is ugly and contemptible stuff that undermines American democracy and shatters trust in the electoral system.  Even worse, it targets vulnerable populations, especially the poor and the ill-educated.  In forthcoming columns, I hope that you'll discuss organizations and methods that combat voter suppression.
